definition: A **phospholipid** is a lipid molecule composed of a <u>glycerol backbone attached to two fatty acid tails and a phosphate group head</u>. Phospholipids are **amphipathic** (having a hydrophobic tail region and hydrophilic head region) and are the <u>primary component of cell membranes, forming lipid bilayers</u>.
tips: In water, phospholipids spontaneously arrange into a **bilayer**: the <u>hydrophobic tails cluster away from water</u>, and the <u>hydrophilic phosphate heads face the water</u>. This self-assembly is what creates cell membranes.

Each phospholipid has <u>two fatty acid "tails" (nonpolar) and one polar "head"</u> (the phosphate group often with an additional polar group like choline or serine). In contrast, a **triglyceride has three fatty acid tails and no polar head** (so triglycerides don't form bilayers).

Because of their **amphipathic nature**, phospholipids allow membranes to be <u>fluid yet selectively permeable</u>: small nonpolar molecules can pass through the hydrophobic core, while charged or large molecules generally cannot without transport proteins.
exam_appearance: If an exam question describes a molecule with <u>"hydrophilic head and two hydrophobic tails"</u> forming membranes, it's describing a **phospholipid**.

Be ready to distinguish a phospholipid from other lipids. For example, a common trap is confusing phospholipids with fats: a <u>triglyceride has 3 fatty acids and is entirely hydrophobic</u>, whereas a <u>phospholipid has 2 fatty acids + a phosphate (making it amphipathic)</u>.

Membrane-related questions often hinge on phospholipid behavior. For instance, "what structural feature of phospholipids enables cell membranes to self-assemble in water-" Answer: their <u>amphipathic nature (dual hydrophobic/hydrophilic properties)</u>.
